Module WitchHunt
Package fr.sos.witchhunt.controller.interactions

Class PlayerCreatorController

java.lang.Object
fr.sos.witchhunt.controller.interactions.PlayerCreatorController
All Implemented Interfaces:
InputSource
public class PlayerCreatorController extends Object implements InputSource

Gathers user-input from an instance of PlayerCreatorPanel active on the Graphical User Interface.

When a user clicks on a button, sends to the InputMediator a newly created Player as long as the user has chosen a valid combination of characteristics.

User-chosen characteristics (whether they are a CPU-controlled player or not, and in this case their name) are gathered on the basis of a PlayerCreatorPanel's JComponents.

Intangible characteristics (the player's id, the name of a CPU-controlled player, and the validity of a Human player's name) are determined on the basis of values stored in the match's instance.

Can be in concurrence with the console version of the player creation interface : see ConcreteInputMediator::createPlayer(int, List, boolean). The first instance of InputSource to post an instance of Player rules over all others, interrupting them and inviting them to create another.

See Also:
  • PlayerCreatorPanel
  • A JCheckbox indicating whether the new player is going to be Human-controlled or not
  • A JTextField containing the new player's future name
  • A JButton that is clicked when the user wants to finalize the creation of a player
  • MatchSetupPanel <#>-- PlayerCreatorPanel
  • Player
  • InputMediator
  • InputMediator::createPlayer(int, List, boolean)
  • post(Player)
  • In concurrence with StdPlayerCreator
  • InputSource

  • Constructor Details

    • PlayerCreatorController

      public PlayerCreatorController(int nthPlayer, int nthCPUPlayer, PlayerCreatorPanel p, List<String> takenNames, InputMediator im)

      Creates the controller and starts listening on each input-gathering JComponent of the given PlayerCreatorPanel :

      - Its JCheckbox's status will indicate whether the new player is going to be Human-controlled or not.

      - Its JTextField will let the user type in a future human-controlled player's name. Its content is automatically updated if the user switches to a CPU-controlled player and vice versa.

      - When clicked, its JButton will check the validity of the provided information : if they are valid, it will create a player, otherwise, it will display why creation failed. This error message will be hidden as soon as the user changes anything.

      Parameters:
      nthPlayer - Value for field nthPlayer
      nthCPUPlayer - Value for field nthCPUPlayer
      p - Value for field pcp
      takenNames - Value for field takenNames
      im - Value for field inputMediator
      See Also:
      • nthPlayer
      • nthCPUPlayer
      • pcp
      • takenNames
      • inputMediator
      • couldNotCreate
      • ActionListener
      • DocumentListener

  • Method Details

    • tryCreatingPlayer

      private void tryCreatingPlayer()

      Checks validity of the user-provided characteristics for the future player and performs adequate operation :

      - Displays a suitable error message if provided information is invalid

      - Creates a player based on the provided information and sends it to the input mediator otherwise.

      Called when the creation button is clicked.

    • destroy

      public void destroy()
      Destroys each and every listener associated to this controller's PlayerCreatorPanel's JComponents.
